citeinfo.title: Geochemical Database for the Brackish Groundwater Assessment of the United States: Major-Ions Dataset
Brackish Groundwater in the United States

descript.abstract: Brackish groundwater (BGW), defined for this assessment as having a dissolved-solids concentration between 1,000 and 10,000 milligrams per liter is an unconventional source of water that may offer a partial solution to current (2016) and future water challenges. In support of the National Water Census, the U.S. Geological Survey has completed a BGW assessment to gain a better understanding of the occurrence and character of BGW resources of the United States as an alternative source of water. Analyses completed as part of this assessment relied on previously collected data from multiple sources, and no new data were collected. One of the most important contributions of this assessment was the creation of a database containing chemical data and aquifer information for the known quantities of BGW in the United States. Data were compiled from single publications to large datasets and from local studies to national assessments, and includes chemical data on the concentrations of dissolved solids, major ions, trace elements, nutrients, radionuclides, and physical properties of the resource (pH, temperature, specific conductance). This dataset represents major-ions data from a compilation of water-quality samples from 16 sources for about 124,000 groundwater wells across the continental U.S., Alaska, Hawaii, Puerto Rico, the U.S. Virgin Islands, Guam, and American Samoa. The data are published here as an ESRI geodatabase with a point feature class, and associated attribute table, and also as non-proprietary comma-separated value table. Major-ions data include information for assessing the geochemical-water type, saturation indices, and potential for mineral scaling. It was not possible to compile all data available for the Nation, and data selected for this investigation were mostly limited to larger datasets that were available in a digital format. As a result, some data on a more local-scale may not be included.
descript.purpose: This dataset was compiled for the purpose of assessing the geochemistry of brackish groundwater across the United States and its territories. Please note that there is a related dataset (https://doi.org/10.5066/F72F7KK1) containing dissolved-solids data that was used for assessing the distribution of brackish groundwater across the United States and its territories.
descript.supplinf:
Data-qualifier codes and brief method descriptions are included with this dataset when possible to provide supporting information for each sample and/or value. Description fields (_desc) were used to convey information about each parameter, such as analysis methods (field is left blank (NULL) if no information was provided by the source). The _desc field is formatted as "[NWIS parameter code]_[constituent] "water" [filtration/method] [units]". Where possible, the values were matched with National Water Information System (NWIS) parameters if enough information about the analysis method was known and the NWIS parameter matched is in the description field. If nothing was known about the methodology, then the non-match with the NWIS parameter is noted. Data-qualifier codes were obtained from original sources if available. Data qualifiers were added if geochemical data values contained inconsistencies (as determined for this assessment) but were not identified by the original source. Definitions of data-qualifier codes (used to populate the “flag” fields) are below (Note: multiple codes may occur in combination within the flag field; this field is left blank if the values are not flagged): < Actual value is known to be less than the value shown > Actual value is known to be greater than the value shown M Presence of material verified but not quantified U Analyzed for, not detected V Contamination analyte was detected in both the environmental sample and the associated blanks. T Concentration of parameter is greater than TDS_mgL field (associated value removed) E Value is estimated A Value is an average BB Unknown meaning (from original source) N Presumptive evidence of presence of material cull Original value from data source marked as cull (associated value removed) Q Unknown meaning (from original data source) H Unknown meaning (from original data source) ppb Original value in parts per billion and no specific gravity supplied to convert to micrograms per liter ppm Original value in parts per million and no specific gravity supplied to convert to milligrams per liter -3333 NA, Not Analyzed, or Unknown -4444 Transcription error or otherwise nonsensical entry (associated value removed)
Values are flagged with an "x" if they meet the following criteria: pH: Field and lab values from the same sample differ by more than one pH unit, or the pH value is less than 4 or greater than 10.5. Dissolved oxygen: Value is less than 0 or greater than 20 milligrams per liter (Dupré and others, 2013, Appendix M). Dissolved solids: Value was less than 7 mg/L or the original value was flagged. Temperature: Value is less than 1 or rather than 100 degrees Celsius. Specific conductance: Lab and Field values differ by plus or minus 10 percent (Dupré and others, 2013, Appendix M) or the value was less than 10 microsiemens per centimeter or the original value was flagged. All other fields: Data value was set to zero but no data-qualifier code was provided by the source (used for fields "Alk_mgL", "Ca_mgL", Cl_mgL", "Dens_gmL", "HCO3_mgL", "Mg_mgL", "Na_mgL", "ph", "SC_uScm", "SO4_mgL", and "TDS_mgL").
References Cited: - Charlton, S.R., and Parkhurst, D.L., 2011, Modules based on the geochemical model PHREEQC for use in scripting and programming languages: Computers & Geosciences, v. 37, no. 10, p. 1653–1663. [Also available at http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.cageo.2011.02.005.] - Dupré, D.H, Scott, J.C., Clark, M.L., Canova, M.G, and Stoker, Y.E., 2013, User’s manual for the National Water Information System of the U.S. Geological Survey: Water-Quality System, Version 5.0: U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report 2013–1054, 730 p.[Also available at http://pubs.usgs.gov/of/2013/1054.] Supersedes Open-File Report 2006–1145. - MacQueen, J., 1967, Some methods for classification and analysis of multivariate observations, in Le Cam, L.M., Nayman, Jerzy, eds., Proceedings of the fifth Berkeley Symposium on mathematical statistics and probability, volume 1—Statistics: Berkeley, Calif., University of California Press, p. 281–297. [Also available at http://projecteuclid.org/euclid.bsmsp/1200512992.] - Miller, J.A., ed., 2000, Ground water atlas of the United States: U.S. Geological Survey Hydrologic Atlas 730, Chapters B–N published separately. [Also available at http://water.usgs.gov/ogw/aquifer/atlas.html.] - Parkhurst, D.L., and Appelo, C.A.J., 2013, Description of input and examples for PHREEQC version 3—A computer program for speciation, batch-reaction, one-dimensional transport, and inverse geochemical calculations: U.S. Geological Survey Techniques and Methods, book 6, chap. A43, 497 p., accessed June 24, 2016. [Also available at http://pubs.usgs.gov/tm/06/a43.] - Parkhurst, D.L., and Appelo, C.A.J., 1999, User's guide to PHREEQC version 2—A computer program for speciation, batch-reaction, one-dimensional transport, and inverse geochemical calculations: U.S. Geological Survey Water-Resources Investigations Report 99–4259, 312 p. [Also available at https://pubs.er.usgs.gov/publication/wri994259.] - R Core Team, 2015, R: A language and environment for statistical computing. R Foundation for Statistical Computing, Vienna, Austria [Also available at https://www.r-project.org/.] - SAS Institute, Inc., 2008, SAS/STAT® 9.2 user’s guide (2d ed.): Cary, N.C., SAS Institute Inc., 7,868 p. [Also available at https://support.sas.com/documentation/cdl/en/statug/63033/HTML/default/viewer.htm#titlepage.htm.] - Sun, R.J., ed., 1986, Regional aquifer-system analysis program of the U.S. Geological Survey—Summary of projects, 1978–84: U.S. Geological Survey Circular 1002, 264 p. [Also available at http://dx.doi.org/10.5066/F7P55KJN.] - U.S. Geological Survey, 2003, Principal Aquifers of the 48 Conterminous United States, Hawaii, Puerto Rico, and the U.S. Virgin Islands: U.S. Geological Survey Web site, digital data, accessed November 17, 2016. idinfo.useconst: The user should read and fully comprehend the metadata prior to data use. This dataset should be used with knowledge of the data limitations as detailed in the “Data Gaps and Limitations” section of USGS Professional Paper 1833 (https://doi.org/10.3133/pp1833).
idinfo.datacred: Various Federal, State, and local agencies and databases contributed to this database. See Lineage portion of the metadata for details.
idinfo.native: Environment as of Metadata Creation: Microsoft Windows 7 Version 6.1 (Build 7601) Service Pack 1; Esri ArcGIS 10.2.2 (Build 3552) Service Pack N/A (Build N/A)

attracc.attraccr: Most sources of groundwater-chemistry data did not provide documentation about sampling, preservation, analytical, and quality-assurance techniques. Several checking routines were used to identify systematic errors in the data and remove those values that were deemed incomplete or unreliable (see the “Data and Methods Used for Analyses” section of USGS professional paper 1833 (https://doi.org/10.3133/pp1833). However, errors are still likely to exist within the datasets. Data from some sources were originally provided as provisional with the expectation that the data may contain inaccurate information. In addition, several errors in the data were brought to the attention of the authors after the analyses were completed. Locations for wells were checked for accuracy and a flag was used (“location_flag”) to represent the reliability of the location information for both the source dataset (was datum known, were locations from GPS, and so forth) and individual well locations (is the well location plotting within the state that is indicated for the sample). See “Horizontal Positional Accuracy Report” section of this metadata for details about the location flag. Also see USGS Professional Paper 1833 (https://doi.org/10.3133/pp1833) section "Geochemical Data". None of the data have been independently verified as part of this assessment’s methods. Despite these limitations, it is expected that data errors represent a small part of the thousands of records, and the generalized results provided within this report are reasonably accurate within the context of a national-scale assessment.

dataqual.logic: All wells selected for analyses were required to include geographic-location coordinates or information that could be used to derive coordinates and either a well-depth measurement or contributing aquifer information. Samples from qualifying wells were selected if they included a measured value for pH, temperature, alkalinity, calcium, chloride, magnesium, potassium, sodium, and sulfate. The most recent sample meeting these requirements was selected for the dataset. Although the same well may exist in the companion dissolved-solids dataset, a different sample was often selected for this dataset based on different criteria. Many of the data sources for this dataset are compilations, and samples are known to be duplicated within and among the sources. If a well appeared to be a duplicate based on location (within 1,000 ft of another well) and depth (within 5 percent difference), then the sample date, dissolved solids, specific conductance, calcium, chloride, potassium, sodium, and magnesium values were compared. If the sample results matched for those values, one of the samples was removed from the data used for analyses. Please see the "Process Steps" section of this metadata for a more detailed discussion.
dataqual.complete: These data were obtained from a wide variety of sources; however, data representing deeper, more saline groundwater were not as readily available and the compiled data are biased toward shallow and fresh water resources (well depth (ft) – 62, 145, 323; 25th, 50th, and 75th percentiles respectively, dissolved-solids concentration (mg/L) – 233, 406, 832; 25th, 50th, and 75th percentiles respectively). It was not possible to compile all data available for the Nation, and data selected for this investigation were mostly limited to larger datasets that were available in a digital format. As a result, some data on a more local-scale of brackish groundwater resources may not be represented. For some groundwater samples, results from multiple methods were reported for a chemical constituent, but a single value was selected for analyses; for example, a sample may include a calcium-concentration result from a filtered and also an unfiltered groundwater sample. In these cases, a prioritization scheme was used to select the best result value available for a sample. In general, filtered samples were selected over unfiltered samples, and common laboratory methods were selected over uncommon laboratory or field methods. For pH and SC, field methods were selected over laboratory methods. Wells were removed from the datasets used for analyses if the selected value to represent maximum depth was less than zero or were not in agreement with other types of depth values for the well; for example, a depth value was not deemed reliable if the total well depth was shallower than depth to the bottom of a well screen. Values of individual constituent measurements were removed if the assigned data-quality codes indicated the value was suspect (data-quality codes "x", "T", -4444, or "cull"), however, the data-quality code remains. The concentration measurement of a major ion, trace element, or nutrient was removed if it was higher than the dissolved-solids concentration of the same sample. Samples that were questionable because they had a dissolved-solids concentration that either did not agree with other dissolved-solids concentrations from different analytical methods for the same sample (that is, if the ratio between the values was >1.12 or <0.90) or was less than the dissolved-solids concentration associated with rainwater, were removed from the dissolved-solids dataset. Also see USGS Professional Paper 1833 sections "Data Sources," "Geochemical Data Selection," and "Data Gaps and Study Limitations".

horizpa.horizpar: Attempts were made to assess the location information for all of the wells where samples were collected. A data-quality code was created called "location_flag" that is a compilation of 2 parts: [Location overview].[Location quality flag]. Location overview conveys what is known about the original accuracy information from the data source (samples with a Location quality flag of 3 and 4 were removed from the dataset): 1 –Datum provided, and location accuracy is reported to be known within 10 seconds. (Only USGS sites meet this criterion because other sources don’t generally provide any indication of the location accuracy) 2 – Datum provided but no location accuracy information 3 – Datum unknown, and location accuracy unknown, but some information is provided about source of latitude/longitude (therefore can make some educated assumptions about the location accuracy) 4 - Datum unknown, or location accuracy unknown, or location accuracy known to be greater than 10 seconds, or location derived from data other than latitude/longitude, such as legal description (such as cadastral or PLSS data). The location quality flag conveys information on where location plots on a map given the location stated in the database: 0 – No issues; location is plotting in the state specified in the database. 1 – Good; location of well plots right along state border or shoreline within the probable accuracy of the state/shoreline dataset used for identifying accuracy of plotting location. Also used for produced water wells that plot offshore but are assumed to be oil/gas wells or test holes. 2 – Fair; well plots slightly further away from state border or shoreline (beyond possible accuracy issues) but still close enough that the state MAY have sampled across the border for some reason or the latitude/longitude is slightly off. May still probably use for analysis but be aware if anything looks different about the data. Special cases may be the Produced Waters version 2.1 dataset, where the latitude/longitude may be for the center of an oil field, in which case, the wells may fall over the border in a neighboring state than the one identified. 3 – Questionable; well plots more further into neighboring state than you would expect for sampling from the bordering state or the well plots well offshore or plots in Canada. Use at your discretion. 4 – Bad; the well plots significantly off the coast or elsewhere in the world. Assumed to be a completely wrong latitude/longitude, transcription error, transposition error, and so forth. Probably should not use.

vertacc.vertaccr: Well depth information was checked against ancillary information and other well construction information for consistency.

procstep.procdesc: Digital tabular data from the sources listed above were received in various formats. Tables (generally in text file or Microsoft Excel file formats) were imported into Microsoft Access. A series of queries was used within Microsoft Access to put each data table into common units and format for inclusion into a master database. For many fields, a description field was added to hold information about the original units of measurement, method descriptions, and/or comments that were in the original datasets from the original sources. Therefore, units in the description field may no longer match the data value. Measurements provided in parts per million (ppm) or parts per billion (ppb) were converted to milligrams per liter or micrograms per liter, respectively, when a specific gravity was provided by multiplying the original value by the specific gravity. If a specific gravity was not provided the original value was kept and coded with either "ppm" or "ppb". For parameters expressed as, for example, “as nitrogen,” values were converted, if needed, using a conversion factor so as to all be in units of “as nitrogen”.

Data from all sources were imported to a Structured Query Language (SQL) server database. Their data format was restructured to match the USGS National Water Information System (NWIS) data model because it represented the largest number of samples in the dataset. This model includes a well description table, a data sample table, and data measurement table. NWIS parameter descriptions were used to describe data measurements when feasible and new parameter descriptions were created when there was not sufficient information to assign them to an existing parameter.

Samples were selected from the master database using the following criteria: (1) well location information and either depth measurement or information that could be used to assign a national aquifer code were available, (2) the most recent sample that provided a pH, temperature, alkalinity, calcium, chloride, magnesium, potassium, sodium, and sulfate measurement, and (3) depth measurement accuracy was not in question.
Since the database was designed not to allow an empty date field, a unique, artificial date of 1800-01-01 was assigned to samples that were not assigned a date by the source agency.

Duplicate wells and samples were identified. Wells were considered to be duplicates if they plotted within 1,000 feet of each other, had well depth values that were within 5 percent of each other, and had samples from the same date with matching dissolved solids, specific conductance (SC), calcium, chloride, potassium, sodium and magnesium.

For some groundwater samples, results from multiple methods were reported for a chemical constituent, but a single value was selected for analyses; for example, a sample may include a calcium-concentration result from a filtered and also an unfiltered groundwater sample. In these cases, a prioritization scheme was used to select the best result value available for a sample. In general, filtered samples were selected over unfiltered samples, and common laboratory methods were selected over uncommon laboratory or field methods. For pH and SC, field methods were selected over laboratory methods. When possible, the method description is including in the “_desc” field associated with each chemical constituent.
Selected samples were retrieved from the SQL server database and exported to a preliminary comma-delimited text file.

The data values in this preliminary table were then compared with values in the original datasets. Three to five samples were chosen from each data source and each of the values in the sample were compared with the original data source value. If this process identified several cases where systematic problems occurred, such as units not being converted correctly, all of the original data were reimported correctly from the source.

Aquifer and brackish groundwater regions were assigned to wells using a combination of automated spatial and manual visual inspection methods. Geospatial datasets of the horizontal and vertical extents of principal aquifers were obtained primarily from previously published USGS reports that were part of the RASA studies (Sun, 1986), Groundwater Availability Studies (http://water.usgs.gov/ogw/gwrp/activities/gw-avail.html), or the Ground Water Atlas of the United States (Miller, 2000) (http://pubs.usgs.gov/ha/ha730/gwa.html). The source citations for all of the aquifers used for the automated method can be found in the table "AquiferExtentSources.xlsx" served with this dataset. The USGS aquifer extent datasets were used to automatically assign an aquifer to wells by location and depth using a GIS. This was completed by comparing well-depth and geologic-formation information with the horizontal and vertical boundaries of the principal aquifers. For wells where this was not possible (no geospatial aquifer extent was available or multiple aquifers were possible), the wells were manually inspected within the GIS to assign aquifers to wells contained by more than one aquifer or those with origination information conflicting with the spatial assignment. Aquifer assignment from the original source was used when available.

The preliminary comma-delimited text file was processed using R® software; an environment for statistical computing and graphics. Temperature, pH, and dissolved oxygen values were identified that were extreme or conflicted with other values of the same parameter. Dissolved solids and specific conductance (SC) values were identified that were extreme or conflicted with each other. Dissolved solids values were calculated from specific conductance values where dissolved-solids concentration, in milligrams per liter was equal to −55+0.689*SC for specific conductance values less than 50,000 microsiemens per centimeter at 25 degrees Celsius (approximately seawater) and dissolved-solids concentration, in milligrams per liter was equal to 27,720−0.0869*SC+6.204*10∧-6*SC∧2 where SC was greater than 50,000 microsiemens per centimeter at 25 degrees Celsius. Values were censored where SC was less than 150 microsiemens per centimeter.

A cluster analysis that implemented the k-means algorithm (MacQueen, 1967; SAS Institute, Inc., 2008) was used to find groups of samples where measures of basic geochemistry were similar within each group, but also were very different from that of samples in other groups, thereby creating geochemically distinct groups. The geochemical group was appended to the major-ions dataset in the attribute field named ”geoch_group”.

The the pH-REdox-Equilibrium computer program (PHREEQC) (Parkhurst and Appelo, 1999) was used to (1) calculate constituent speciation and mineral saturation indexes (SIs)(Parkhurst and Appelo, 2013; Charlton and Parkhurst, 2011) and (2) simulate processes including dilution, evaporation, and a hypothetical treatment process resembling reverse osmosis (RO) . To simulate evaporation, pure water was removed from solution to produce concentration factors of 1 (0 percent of the water removed), 2 (50 percent of the water remove), 4 (75 percent of the water removed), 8 (87.5 percent of the water removed), and 16 (about 94 percent of water removed)(represented by the "_1x", "_2x", "_4x", "_8x", and "_16x" appended to the field names representing modeled amounts of precipitate). Simulations were completed under open (pCO2 = 10^-3.4) and closed (no pCO2) atmospheric conditions with respect to the partial pressure of carbon dioxide (pCO2). The first simulation step (step “0”) was completed under approximated “groundwater conditions” of 15 degrees Celsius and a pressure of 1 atmosphere. Subsequent steps to approximate RO were completed at 25 degrees Celsius and pressures of 20 atmospheres (also see U.S. Geological Survey Professional Paper 1833, section "Analytical Methods/Geochemical Characterization").

Geochemical properties were calculated from chemical analyses of saline-water samples by PHREEQC and output from that analysis was appended to this dataset. These fields are named "model_xxxxx", where xxxxx indicate varying parameters.
Proprietary data were identified and location information was removed for those records.

Final files were processed with the statistical package R (R Core Team, 2015) to produce a set of charts and tables describing the range for each constituent and the flags describing them. Applicable constituents were compared to TDS to identify any values that were not in agreement across samples. This identified any disparities in measurement units as well as errors that were presented during processing and they were corrected. The resulting charts and tables were used throughout the project to ensure data consistency and prevent systematic errors.

The arcpy (Python version 2.7) library was used in a python script to load csv files into an ArcGIS geodatabase. A schema.ini file was created to describe the columns and their associated data types and was placed in the same directory as the csv files. The files were loaded into the python session as tables, then converted to a feature layer with a spatial reference of NAD83. The resulting layers were projected to USA Contiguous Albers Equal Area Conic projection and saved to the geodatabase. The code used is as follows: import arcpy
arcpy.env.workspace = "F:/Alta/Brackish/BrackishWater_QC.gdb" fclistq = arcpy.ListFeatureClasses() + arcpy.ListTables() for cfq in fclistq: arcpy.Delete_management(cfq)
arcpy.env.workspace = "F:/Alta/Brackish/BrackishWater.gdb" fclist = arcpy.ListFeatureClasses() + arcpy.ListTables()
for cf in fclist: arcpy.Delete_management(cf)
spref = r"Favorites\Nad 1983" sprefNew = r"Coordinate Systems\USGS_Favorites\USA Contiguous Albers Equal Area Conic USGS.prj"
arcpy.TableToTable_conversion("F:/Alta/Brackish/BrackishFiles/BrackishFiles_2015_12_31b/Diss_Solids_2015_12_31_final.csv", "F:/Alta/Brackish/BrackishWater.gdb", "TDS_filt_p") arcpy.TableToTable_conversion("F:/Alta/Brackish/BrackishFiles/BrackishFiles_2015_12_31b/Major_Ions_2015_12_31_final.csv", "F:/Alta/Brackish/BrackishWater.gdb", "MajorIons_filt_Phreeqc_p")
arcpy.MakeXYEventLayer_management("MajorIons_filt_Phreeqc_p", "dec_long_va", "dec_lat_va", "XY_MajorIons_filt_Phreeqc_p", spref) arcpy.CopyFeatures_management ("XY_MajorIons_filt_Phreeqc_p", "XY_MajorIons_filt_Phreeqc_p_save")
arcpy.Project_management("XY_MajorIons_filt_Phreeqc_p_save", "Major_Ions", sprefNew)
arcpy.MakeXYEventLayer_management("TDS_filt_p", "dec_long_va", "dec_lat_va", "XY_TDS_filt_p", spref) arcpy.CopyFeatures_management ("XY_TDS_filt_p", "XY_TDS_filt_p_save")
arcpy.Project_management("XY_TDS_filt_p_save", "Diss_Solids", sprefNew)
arcpy.Delete_management("XY_MajorIons_filt_Phreeqc_p_save") arcpy.Delete_management("MajorIons_filt_phreeqc_p") arcpy.Delete_management("XY_MajorIons_filt_Phreeqc_p")
arcpy.Delete_management("TDS_filt_p") arcpy.Delete_management("XY_TDS_filt_p") arcpy.Delete_management("XY_TDS_filt_p_save")

Describes the accuracy of the location data. Comprised of 2 parts: [Location overview].[Location quality flag]. See Horizontal Accuracy section for details.

edom.edomvd: Location overview: Datum provided, and location accuracy is reported to be known within 10 seconds. Location quality: No issues; location is plotting in the state specified in the database.

Location overview: Datum provided, and location accuracy is reported to be known within 10 seconds. Location quality: Good; location of well plots right along the state border or shoreline and is within the probable accuracy of the state or shoreline dataset used for identifying the accuracy of the plotting location. If well plots just offshore, it is assumed to be a produced water well associated with oil and gas wells or test holes.

Location overview: Datum provided, and location accuracy is reported to be known within 10 seconds. Location quality: Fair; well plots slightly outside the state border or shoreline and cannot be explained by reasonable accuracy issues.
Location overview: Datum provided but there is no location accuracy information. Location quality: No issues; location is plotting in the state specified in the database.

Location overview: Datum provided but there is no location accuracy information. Location quality: Good; location of well plots right along the state border or shoreline and is within the probable accuracy of the state or shoreline dataset used for identifying the accuracy of the plotting location. If well plots just offshore, it is assumed to be a produced water well associated with oil and gas wells or test holes.

Location overview: Datum or location accuracy is unknown, but some information is provided about the source of the coordinates. Location quality: No issues; location is plotting in the state specified in the database.

Location overview: Datum or location accuracy is unknown, location accuracy is known to be greater than 10 seconds, or the location is derived from data other than coordinates, such as a legal description. Location quality: No issues; location is plotting in the state specified in the database.

Location overview: Datum or location accuracy is unknown, location accuracy is known to be greater than 10 seconds, or the location is derived from data other than coordinates, such as a legal description. Location quality: Good; location of well plots right along the state border or shoreline and is within the probable accuracy of the state or shoreline dataset used for identifying the accuracy of the plotting location. If well plots just offshore, it is assumed to be a produced water well associated with oil and gas wells or test holes.
Proprietary. Data were obtained from a proprietary source and permission was not granted to release location information.

attr.attrdef: Site use code (NWIS)

edom.edomvd: Not known, or not provided
Hole used as an electrical anode. This category includes wells used solely to ground pipelines or electronic relays and other installations

A site that is no longer in existence. The casing of most destroyed wells will be pulled, but some may be plugged or filled. This category does not include an abandoned site that merely is not in use.
The drainage of surface water to the subsurface.
A water-supply source that is used only when the principal supply of water is unavailable.
A hole drilled for geothermal energy development. This category includes "dry" geothermal wells or wells into which water is injected for heating.
A well in which a fluid is circulated in a closed system. Water is neither added to, nor removed from, the aquifer.
Any tunnel, shaft, or other excavation constructed for the extraction of minerals.
A cased test-hole or well, drilled for either water-level or water quality observations.

Any well or hole drilled in search of, or for production of, petroleum or gas. It includes any oil or gas production well, dry hole, core hole, injection well drilled for secondary recovery of oil, etc.

A site constructed or converted for use in replenishing the aquifer. This category includes wells that are used to return water to the aquifer after use, such as those for returning air-conditioning water.
A hole for pumping water into an aquifer in order to increase the pressure in the aquifer for a specific purpose, for example, water flood purposes in oil fields.
A hole drilled for seismic exploration.

An uncased hole (or one cased only temporarily) that was drilled for water, or for geologic or hydrogeologic testing. It may be equipped temporarily with a pump in order to make a pumping test, but if the well is destroyed after testing is completed, it is still a test hole. A core hole drilled as a part of mining or quarrying exploration work is included in this category.

An abandoned water-supply site or one for which no use is contemplated. At an abandoned farmstead, a well originally used for domestic purposes may be classed as unused, even though it is equipped with a pump. Similarly, a stock well with a pump may become unused when a pasture or corral is put into cultivation. An irrigation well that is not equipped with a pump, nor used because the yield is too low or the water is too mineralized, is included in this category.

A site used to convey industrial waste, domestic sewage, oil-field brine, mine drainage, radioactive waste, or other waste fluid into an underground zone. An oil-test or deep water well converted to waste disposal is included in this category.
A site that supplies water for one of the purposes shown under use of water. It includes a dewatering well, if the dewatering is accomplished by pumping groundwater.
Groundwater sites that are used to both withdraw water from and inject water to a well, such as an irrigation well used to return water to the aquifer during nonpumping periods.

attr.attrdef: Water use code (NWIS)

edom.edomvd: Not known, or not provided
A water supply used solely or principally for heating or cooling a building.
Water used for fish hatcheries and fish farms.
Water that is bottled for potable purposes (see Medicinal).
Water used by commercial facilities such as hotels, restaurants, office buildings, educational institutions, prisons, government and military facilities, and retail sales stores.
Water that is pumped and distributed to several homes.
Water used in a desalting process whereby dissolved solids are removed to make water potable or suitable for other uses.

Water pumped for dewatering a construction or mining site, or to lower the water table for agricultural purposes. In this respect, it differs from a drainage well that is used to drain surface water underground.
Water for household purposes, such as drinking, food preparation, bathing, washing clothes and dishes, flushing toilets, and watering lawns and gardens. This is also called residential water use.

Site constructed principally for fire protection, even though the water may be used at times to supplement an industrial or public supply, to irrigate a golf course, fill a swimming pool, or for other use.
Water for such purposes as processing, washing, and cooling in facilities that manufacture products.
A water supply used solely for cooling industrial machines.

Water used in the maintenance and operation of institutions such as large schools, universities, hospitals, rest homes, or similar installations. Owners of institutions may be individuals, corporations, churches, or governmental units.
Artificial application of water on lands to assist in the growing of crops and pastures or to maintain vegetative growth in recreational lands such as parks and golf courses.
Water used for livestock watering, feed lots, dairy operations, and other on-farm needs.
Water purported to have therapeutic value. Water may be used for bathing and/or drinking.

Water used for extracting minerals occurring naturally, including solids such as coal and ores, liquids such as crude petroleum, and gases such as natural gas. Mining also includes uses associated with quarrying, well operations, milling, and other preparations customarily done at the mine site or as part of a mining activity.
Well is only used for monitoring purposes.
Miscellaneous uses not included in the listed categories.
A site that is no longer in existence or use. The casing of most destroyed wells will be pulled, but some may be plugged or filled.
Water used for generation of any type of power.
Private well
Water that is pumped and distributed to several homes.
Water used in support of recreational activities, other than drinking water supply.
Unknown use
Water is unused, such as a monitoring well.

attr.attrdef: The principal aquifer name used for the associated report. Aquifer names come from the publication Principal Aquifers of the 48 Conterminous United States, Hawaii, Puerto Rico, and the U.S. Virgin Islands (U.S. Geological Survey, 2003), the Groundwater Atlas of the United States (Miller, 2000), or are defined by this project.
attr.attrdefs: U.S. Geological Survey, 2003; Miller, 2000; Producer defined

attr.attrdef: The method used to determine the principal aquifer encountered by the well

edom.edomvd: GIS methodologies were used to determine in which aquifer the well was completed. Wells shallower than 3,000 feet and not already assigned an aquifer by automated methods were selected and compared within a GIS to the extents and depths of principal aquifer boundaries. Using ancillary information such as publications about the aquifer, an aquifer was assigned to the well. If a well fell outside the given principal aquifer extent but other ancillary data indicated that the well is screened in the principal aquifer’s rock units, it was assigned to that aquifer.
Could not determine aquifer

The source information was corrected based on independent geologic ancillary information and professional knowledge/judgement or there was only local geologic formation name. If no aquifer information was provided, professional judgement was used to assign the well to a national aquifer.
Principal aquifer was defined by the data source

attr.attrdef: The date the sample was taken in yyyy-mm-dd format. Values were set to 1800-01-01 if no date was provided

edom.edomvd: Description

attr.attrdef: Data-qualifier code for dissolved solids. Values are obtained from original sources if available. If the values contained inconsistencies but were not flagged by the original source, flags were added.

edom.edomvd: Actual value is known to be less than the value shown
Actual value is known to be greater than the value shown

attr.attrdef: Integer values 1-4 describing the quality of the best available dissolved-solids data that was selected to be the TDS_mgL value. Note: If more than one dissolved-solids value was provided and the value of [TDS_mgL]/[TDS other] was greater than 1.12 or less than .90, TDS_mgL_quality was set to "4" - do not use.

edom.edomvd: Dissolved solids analysis completed, method known.
Dissolved solids analysis completed, and the method or sample date is unknown.

Estimated from the best available specific conductance value using an equation developed by using regression on samples where both a preferred specific conductance (SC_uScm) and a dissolved-solids values were reported; If SC_uScm was less than 50,000 microsiemens per centimeter, then: TDS_mgL = -55 + 0.689 * SC_uScm. If SC_uScm was greater than 50,000 then the relation was not linear: TDS_mgL = -27,720 - 0.0869 * SC_uScm + 6.204x10^-6 * SC_uScm^2
Do not use. Value was removed from sample record.

edom.edomvd: Description
All values were converted to degrees Fahrenheit, 32 was subtracted from the value and was then multiplied by a conversion factor of 0.5555556.

overview.eaover: The entity and attribute information provided here describes the tabular data associated with the dataset. Please review the detailed descriptions that are provided (the individual attribute descriptions) for information on the values that appear as fields/table entries of the dataset.
overview.eadetcit: The entity and attribute information was generated by the individual and/or agency identified as the originator of the dataset. Please review the rest of the metadata record for additional details and information.

cntaddr.address: Denver Federal Center, Building 810, Mail Stop 302

distinfo.distliab: Any use of trade, firm, or product names is for descriptive purposes only and does not imply endorsement by the U.S. Government. The data have been approved for release and publication by the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS). Although the data have been subjected to rigorous review and are substantially complete, the USGS reserves the right to revise the data pursuant to further analysis and review. Furthermore, the data are released on the condition that neither the USGS nor the U.S. Government may be held liable for any damages resulting from authorized or unauthorized use. Although the data have been processed successfully on a computer system at the U.S. Geological Survey, no warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the display or utility of the data on any other system, or for general or scientific purposes, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty. The U.S. Geological Survey shall not be held liable for improper or incorrect use of the data described and/or contained herein. Users of the data are advised to read all metadata and associated documentation thoroughly to understand appropriate use and data limitations.

stdorder.fees: None. No fees are applicable for obtaining the dataset.
